ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Information about primate diet, socialization, environments, etc.
Understanding of primate evolution, ecology and social behavior.
I developed a wide array of knowledge about primates, mostly nonhuman but also partly human.

I learned a ton about primates and their lives, societies, and ecosystems. I had no exposure to really any biology before taking this and it was incredible. Primates are such fascinating animals (us included, though I like orangutans better I think). It was really eye-opening to learn about all the intricacies of primate development and socialization and behavior and we touched on conservation as well, though there's a separate class on that if that's what you're looking for.
primate ecology, realtionships between humans and primates
I learned a lot about primate behavior, which helped me understand some of the human phenomena that I witness in everyday life.
General knowledge about primate behavior and ecology, literature reviewing skills, and scientific writing.
Knowledge of primate mating, nutrition, cooperation. Insights into the relationship between human and non-human primate behavior.

Understanding the overall historical and anthropological understanding of primates. The class is straightforward and provides the information on the content and students are expected to keep up with course content with several assessments such as reading critiques, longer-papers, and discussion sections to enhance the overall knowledge and insights from the class. This class doesn't really teach transferable technical skills, but helps being more critical when understanding things and helps with reading research journals that are dense.
Broad survey of mostly nonhuman primate behavior.

I learned about different primate species and their environments, diets, anatomy, and social structures. I particularly enjoyed learning about their different type so social systems, particularly their social hiearchies.
I learned about the important aspects of primatology and gained experience critiquing readings on primates.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Prof. Watts and TA (Alex) were both super nice, knowledgable, and understanding. Written assignments were frequent but small so they were very manageable, and they were quite flexible so you were able to write about what most interested you. Feedback from the prof and TA was also super detailed. Lecture was sometimes slow.
very interesting course, the lectures were very engaging.
Strength: very good introduction to how and why primates behave in certain ways, which helps understand human behavior at least partly.

Weaknesses: the powerpoints could be more organized 
Strengths: interesting content, engaged and understanding professor, easy to get deadline extensions
the material is interesitng, but it was not presented in  asuper engaging way.

Strengths: Organization of topics across lectures, reading critiques were cool assignments

Weaknesses: Can't think of any
There was no feedback on assignments that helped you improve.

Strengths: really interesting lectures chock-full of information, and its always great to hear David Watts perspective on what he has researched for so long (chimpanzees for ~30 years!); readings were relevant and interesting, and not too long! I also appreciate that there are recommended readings, in case theres a topic you find particularly interesting and want to research further; writing assignments and take-home exams were manageable and interesting; recorded all lectures, which was great during the pandemic and as someone with a chronic illness. All around a great course.
Weaknesses: the only one I can think of is that sometimes sections were super unstructured, and although I really liked sections and the TA was really awesome, I did wish that there was more of a plan for sections, even just a teeny, tiny bit more structure, rather than just discussion based on whatever points people happened to bring up.
The class structure was pretty mundane. The lectures weren't engaging. The strength was that the teaching members were very knowledge about the material was made it better.

Strengths: Super knowledgable professor, cool material, assignments were communicated beforehand on syllabus which was nice. Professor and TA were always super helpful and flexible when need be. Assignments weren't too difficult and kept you engaged with readings. Workload wasn't super heavy. 
Weaknesses: Sometimes material felt repetitive.
I think many of the topics we covered we very interesting, particularly the social systems of the primates.
I think the course could be improved by making the readings a little easier to locate, making discussion sections more interactive, and having clearer instructions for the writing assignments.
Professor Watts was very knowledgable about everything he was teaching, which made the class very interesting. The assignments were all accessible despite my limited prior knowledge on the topic.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I recommend for a low workload, different and interesting class that also counts as a science credit!
Yes if they have an interest in ecologies, primates, or animal behavior in general.

Yes, this is a fantastic course if you are interested in monkeys/primates. Be aware that it is not a gut though. There are six papers throughout the term and there is enough writing that the course could be worth a writing credit. However, I found the papers very easy to write because the material was very engaging. There are no quizzes/timed exams, so there is less of an emphasis on memorization and immediate recall. The readings are helpful to understand the lecture material, but I mainly referenced them as I was writing.
Yes, especially for those interested in cognitive science or ecology.
Yeah, I barely went to class and the assignments were easy and the prof was nice

no really, except if you are really interested in reading papers about primates. i thought that the course will be more interesting, but the way it was presented did not work for me. i was not engaged and could not pay attention. I needed more stimulation and readings that were more interesting. i wish i learn more about what day-to-day lives of the primates in the wild are like and did some field trips where I could learn from hands-on expeirnce. I liked when we saw videos and observed bones in seciotn. i wish there was more of that.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in primates.

You're either looking at this course as a gut social science credit, or as an anthropology major. If you're the latter, you should almost definitely take this course -- all the people in the class who were majors seemed to be ecstatic about it. Otherwise, the multitude of papers, the boring sections, and the lack of responsibility for any of the material (which means you have no reason to pay attention to David's lectures, as great as they are) means you could probably do better elsewhere.
ye

Yes, primatology is so fascinating and beautiful. Prof. Watts is lovely and so was the TA. Thanks to this course I am obsessed with bonobos now. I hope I get reincarnated as a female bonobo is my next life.

Yes! Great low-stress, non-major course if you have even a passing interest in primates. You pick up some cool knowledge and get to know if further study is right for you, and the course won't demand too much of your time.
Gut class that's interesting and not something you'll learn about otherwise unless you're into the subject.
No. Unless you see primatology as your future career, or find non-human primates so interesting that it is worth expending a credit d/f, do not take this course.

Yes! Its a great overview of primates, what we know about them, why we study them, and what issues researchers and scientists are currently working on. If you have no interest at all in primates, animals, the environment, etc., then this probably isnt the class for you, but if youre interested in at least one of those things, I think you should check it out! Itll also help you develop your skills for reading, understanding, and even evaluating/critiquing scientific papers.
I think it's a fun class if you are interested in primates. Learning about them helped me gain a deeper understanding of human behavior to a certain extent
Yes, if the student has an interest in primates this course certainly covers that.
Yes.
